item.title: How To Make A Server Status Checker With PHP
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Elijah, post:9, topic:214852”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=282533.msg2820939#msg2820939 date=1244594651]
I have cleaned this thread of spam, capitalizing every word may be pointless, but you don’t have to read the thread, just move on rather than comment about it.

Personally, I believe that all server status pages are horrible, no matter how well they’re programmed. Why? Because when you ping a server and send the status back to the client, then they are told if the server is up or down, but what if the server got taken down/put up right when you received the results? Yes, I know this is a very rare occurance, but it is possible.

Still it is better than each individual person having to ‘ping’ each server to see if it is online or not right? Also server status pages can keep uptime information, which can give you valuable insight into the reliability of the server. Good serverstatus pages don’t just ‘ping’ servers anyway, my new one for example will actually completely log in and log out of the private server to make sure it is online and functioning.
[/quote]

Wow you’re cool. Thanks for giving me a warning for a year old post.[/quote]

Haha, sorry about that Elijah, I guess I saw June and figured it was recent. I removed it.

Read full topic

Personally, I believe that all server status pages are horrible, no matter how well they’re programmed. Why? Because when you ping a server and send the status back to the client, then they are told if the server is up or down, but what if the server got taken down/put up right when you received the results? item.title: How To Make A Server Status Checker With PHP
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I have cleaned this thread of spam, capitalizing every word may be pointless, but you don’t have to read the thread, just move on rather than comment about it.

zachera:

Personally, I believe that all server status pages are horrible, no matter how well they’re programmed. Why? Because when you ping a server and send the status back to the client, then they are told if the server is up or down, but what if the server got taken down/put up right when you received the results? Yes, I know this is a very rare occurance, but it is possible.

Still it is better than each individual person having to ‘ping’ each server to see if it is online or not right? Also server status pages can keep uptime information, which can give you valuable insight into the reliability of the server. Good serverstatus pages don’t just ‘ping’ servers anyway, my new one for example will actually completely log in and log out of the private server to make sure it is online and functioning.

Read full topic

Yes, I know this is a very rare occurance, but it is possible.

if (! $sock = @fsockopen($ip, $port, $num, $error, 5))

Doesn’t look like a ping to me.

item.title: How To Make A Server Status Checker With PHP
item.dc:creator: @The_Almost The Almost
item.description:
@The_Almost wrote:

Purpose:To Make A Server Status Checker In PHP

Step 1:Go To Your WebSite and Make A New Page Called StatucCheck.PHP and add this code you can change the backgrounds and other details if you wish.

<? $ip = "youriphere"; $port = "yourporthere"; if (! $sock = @fsockopen($ip, $port, $num, $error, 5)) echo '<B><FONT COLOR=red>Offline</b></FONT>'; else{ echo '<B><FONT COLOR=lime>Online</b></FONT>'; fclose($sock); } ?>

Credits:100% The Almost

Read full topic
